abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            portable water that improves life for millions in Manila.
            Over the past 15 years, Manila’s growing urban population
            has demanded a significant increase in water supply and
            sanitation services and facilities. The local
            concessionaires, the Manila Water Company Inc. (MWCI) and
            Maynilad Water Services Inc. (MWSI) were needed to upgrade
            their piped water supply and sanitation coverage due to
            expanding franchise areas. To address the challenge, the
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            set out to promote greater private sector participation to
            improve the sector. IBRD’s involvement in water concessions
            was based on the rationale that the private sector can play
            an important role in delivering services. MWCI and IBRD
            implemented Manila Second Sewerage Project to improve the
            quality of wastewater and septage management service in
            Manila and expand MWCI’s sewerage and septage management
            program. The Manila Third Sewerage Project enhanced septage
            management, piloted a combined sewer-drainage system
            approach and promoted advocacy campaigns on the negative
            environmental impacts of wastewater. Through capital
            infusion, debt restructuring and infrastructure
            rehabilitation, both concessionaires managed to accelerate
            and enhance supply across their franchise areas. MWCI posted
            a dramatic increase in 24-hour water supply, to 99 percent
            in 2009 from 26 percent in 1997. MWCI’s investment program
            reduced the risk of sicknesses from exposure to sewage
            contamination, which is estimated to have reduced mortality
            by 20 percent. IBRD has supported two utilities in expanding
            affordable and efficient water and sewerage services to
            benefit some 107,000 poor households.
